            "mainEntityOfPage": {

                "url": "https://www.euronews.com/business/2023/12/19/why-are-europeans-paying-more-for-their-iphones"
            },
            "headline": "Why does your iPhone cost hundreds more in Europe than in the US? ",
            "description": "The recently-launched iPhone 15 Pro Max is selling for an eye-watering $1199 in the US, but how do prices differ in Europe?",
            "articleBody": "If you\u2019re in the Eurozone and you want to buy the top of the range iPhone, it\u2019s going to cost you more than buyers across the pond. Converted into euros, the price displayed on Apple\u2019s US website starts at \u20ac1131.74 for the iPhone 15 Pro Max,  which went on sale in September . This is a price hike of around 9% compared to last year\u2019s version, but for European consumers, Americans are arguably bagging a bargain. The price in European stores varies between countries, but it\u2019s usually significantly higher than in the US. In France, the iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at \u20ac1,479, in Germany it\u2019s \u20ac1,449, and in Italy, consumers pay \u20ac1,489. When it comes to Apple\u2019s less expensive phones, you\u2019ll also notice a price jump. In the US, the basic iPhone 15 sells for an equivalent of \u20ac754.18. Back in Europe, it\u2019s priced at \u20ac969 in France, \u20ac949 in Germany, and \u20ac979 in Italy. But before you book your next holiday to America, it\u2019s important to look more closely at these numbers. A key reason for the higher prices is that VAT is included in the European figures, whereas extra fees are added after purchase in the US. Tax rates depend on which state you\u2019re in, but these generally sit between 2.9% to 7.25%. If you wanted to buy an iPhone 15 Pro Max in Washington, DC, where the sales tax is 6%, you would therefore be charged an extra $71.94 (\u20ac67.90) at the checkout. To take Los Angeles, where the sales tax is particularly high, you would be charged an extra $113.91 (\u20ac107.52). So, to tally those figures up, a customer in LA will save \u20ac239.74 when buying Apple\u2019s most expensive phone, compared to a customer in France.\u00a0 And the price gap between the US and the EU isn\u2019t a phenomenon that\u2019s exclusive to Apple\u2019s new generation of products. When the iPhone X was launched in 2017, Twitter users joked that it would be cheaper to fly to the US and buy the device, rather than buying it in Europe. But whilst this may be a good excuse for a holiday, the reality is a little more complicated. This is because you are legally required to pay customs duties when re-entering the EU with valuable items. If you are travelling on a plane or a ship, you need to declare goods over \u20ac430, and for\u00a0other transport modes, this threshold is at \u20ac300. If you were to fly back from the US to France, the customs duties on the iPhone 15 Pro Max would therefore cost you over \u20ac200. Along with the added travel costs, this definitely wouldn\u2019t save any money. So ultimately, the reason for Apple\u2019s higher prices is not entirely clear, but there\u2019s also no way for Europeans to avoid them. Addressing the issue in 2016, the company said it sets international product prices based on a range of factors, such as \u201ccurrency exchange rates, local import laws, business practices, taxes, and the cost of doing business\u201d. \u201cThese factors vary from region to region and over time, such that international prices are not always comparable to US suggested retail prices,\u201d Apple said. Yet even if Apple is making consumers pay more to cover extra operating charges, this hasn\u2019t seemed to dent the company\u2019s success. iPhones account for around a quarter of smartphone sales in the EU, surpassed only by Samsung models. ",

","versionId":"7","plainText":"If you\u2019re in the Eurozone and you want to buy the top of the range iPhone, it\u2019s going to cost you more than buyers across the pond. \n\nConverted into euros, the price displayed on Apple\u2019s US website starts at \u20ac1131.74 for the iPhone 15 Pro Max,  which went on sale in September . \n\nThis is a price hike of around 9% compared to last year\u2019s version, but for European consumers, Americans are arguably bagging a bargain. \n\nThe price in European stores varies between countries, but it\u2019s usually significantly higher than in the US. In France, the iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at \u20ac1,479, in Germany it\u2019s \u20ac1,449, and in Italy, consumers pay \u20ac1,489. \n\nWhen it comes to Apple\u2019s less expensive phones, you\u2019ll also notice a price jump. In the US, the basic iPhone 15 sells for an equivalent of \u20ac754.18. Back in Europe, it\u2019s priced at \u20ac969 in France, \u20ac949 in Germany, and \u20ac979 in Italy. \n\nBut before you book your next holiday to America, it\u2019s important to look more closely at these numbers. \n\nA key reason for the higher prices is that VAT is included in the European figures, whereas extra fees are added after purchase in the US. \n\nTax rates depend on which state you\u2019re in, but these generally sit between 2.9% to 7.25%. If you wanted to buy an iPhone 15 Pro Max in Washington, DC, where the sales tax is 6%, you would therefore be charged an extra $71.94 (\u20ac67.90) at the checkout. \n\nTo take Los Angeles, where the sales tax is particularly high, you would be charged an extra $113.91 (\u20ac107.52). \n\nSo, to tally those figures up, a customer in LA will save \u20ac239.74 when buying Apple\u2019s most expensive phone, compared to a customer in France.\u00a0 \n\nAnd the price gap between the US and the EU isn\u2019t a phenomenon that\u2019s exclusive to Apple\u2019s new generation of products. \n\nWhen the iPhone X was launched in 2017, Twitter users joked that it would be cheaper to fly to the US and buy the device, rather than buying it in Europe. \n\nBut whilst this may be a good excuse for a holiday, the reality is a little more complicated. \n\nThis is because you are legally required to pay customs duties when re-entering the EU with valuable items. \n\nIf you are travelling on a plane or a ship, you need to declare goods over \u20ac430, and for\u00a0other transport modes, this threshold is at \u20ac300. If you were to fly back from the US to France, the customs duties on the iPhone 15 Pro Max would therefore cost you over \u20ac200. Along with the added travel costs, this definitely wouldn\u2019t save any money. \n\nSo ultimately, the reason for Apple\u2019s higher prices is not entirely clear, but there\u2019s also no way for Europeans to avoid them. \n\nAddressing the issue in 2016, the company said it sets international product prices based on a range of factors, such as \u201ccurrency exchange rates, local import laws, business practices, taxes, and the cost of doing business\u201d. \n\n\u201cThese factors vary from region to region and over time, such that international prices are not always comparable to US suggested retail prices,\u201d Apple said. \n\nYet even if Apple is making consumers pay more to cover extra operating charges, this hasn\u2019t seemed to dent the company\u2019s success. \n\niPhones account for around a quarter of smartphone sales in the EU, surpassed only by Samsung models. \n\n","advertising":0,"advertisingData":{"startDate":0,"endDate":0,"slug":null,"title":null,"disclaimerLabelKey":null,"sponsor":null,"sponsorName":null,"sponsorUrl":null,"sponsorLogo":"","sponsorLogoReverse":"","isDfp":0},"isLiveCoverage":false,"canonical":"https:\/\/www.euronews.com\/business\/2023\/12\/19\/why-are-europeans-paying-more-for-their-iphones","houseNumber":"230926_BUSU_53232068","isBreakingNews":false,"type":"normal","numberWords":566,"isOpinion":false,"grapeshotCategories":["'gv_safe'","'gb_safe'","'gb_safe_from_high'","'gb_safe_from_high_med'","'pos_equinor'","'pos_facebook'","'pos_pmi'","'pos_ukraine-russia'","'pos_ukrainecrisis'","'gs_busfin'","'gs_science_geography'","'gs_science'","'gs_busfin_business'","'gs_shopping_misc'","'gs_tech'","'gs_tech_consumer_smartphone'","'gs_tech_phones'"],"versions":{"en":{"fullUrl":"\/business\/2023\/12\/19\/why-are-europeans-paying-more-for-their-iphones","url":"why-are-europeans-paying-more-for-their-iphones","title":"Why does your iPhone cost hundreds more in Europe than in the US?     /* container rendering ------ */
#didomi-host {
    font-family: 'Inter', 'Open Sans', sans-serif;
}
#didomi-host div:empty {
    display: none;
}

@media screen and (max-width: 768px) {
    #didomi-host .didomi-exterior-border {
        margin-inline: 16px !important;
    }
}

#didomi-host .didomi-popup__backdrop.didomi-notice-popup.didomi-support-full-height .didomi-exterior-border .didomi-popup-container {
    max-width: 600px !important;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-popup-backdrop {
    background-color: hsla(0,0%,100%,0.95);
}

/* ne pas afficher les finalités ------ */
html[lang="fr"] #didomi-host .didomi-notice-data-processing-container.didomi-popup-notice-data-processing-list,
html[lang="es"] #didomi-host .didomi-notice-data-processing-container.didomi-popup-notice-data-processing-list {
    display: none;
}

/* popup ------ */
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-view {
    padding-top: 24px !important;
    position: relative;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-exterior-border{
    border: none;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-popup-container {
    border: none;
    border-radius: 10px;
    box-shadow:0px 0px 3px rgb(0 0 0 / 50%);
}

/* logo ------ */
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-view .didomi-popup-notice-logo-container {
    display: flex;
    padding-inline: 24px;
    order: 1;
    z-index: 1 !important;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-popup-view .didomi-popup-notice-logo-container .didomi-popup-notice-logo {
    --ew-logo-size: 48px;
    margin-bottom: 0!important;
    width: var(--ew-logo-size);
    height: var(--ew-logo-size);
    aspect-ratio: 1/1;
}

/* continue without agreein link ------ */
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-view .didomi-continue-without-agreeing {
    --ew-logo-size: 48px;
    display: flex;
    justify-content: flex-end;
    align-items: center;
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: 0;
    height: var(--ew-logo-size);
    margin-bottom: 0!important;
    order: 2;
    padding-block: 0 !important;
    padding-inline: 72px 24px;
    position: absolute;
    text-decoration-color: #0172F0;
    width: 100%;
    z-index: 2 !important;
}
@media screen and (min-width: 1024px) {
    #didomi-host .didomi-popup-view .didomi-continue-without-agreeing {
        transform: translateY(10px);
    }
}

#didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after {
    content: 'Continuer sans accepter';
    color: #0172F0;
    font-size: 12px;
    text-align: center;
}

html[lang="en"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Continue without agreeing'; }
html[lang="fr"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Continuer sans accepter'; }
html[lang="de"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Weiter ohne Zustimmung'; }
html[lang="it"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Continua senza accettare'; }
html[lang="es"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Continuar sin aceptar'; }
html[lang="pt"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Continuar sem aceitar'; }
html[lang="pl"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Kontynuuj bez wyrażania zgody'; }
html[lang="ru"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Продолжить без согласия'; }
html[lang="tr"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Kabul etmeden devam edin'; }
html[lang="gr"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Συνεχίστε χωρίς να συμφωνείτε'; }
html[lang="hu"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'Folytatás beleegyezés nélkül'; }
html[lang="fa"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'ادامه بدون پذیرش'; }
html[lang="ar"] #didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-continue-without-agreeing:after { content: 'مواصلة دون موافقة'; }

/* text rendering ------ */
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-view .didomi-popup-notice-text-container {
    order: 3;
    padding: 16px 24px 0 24px !important;
    line-height: normal !important;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-popup-container .didomi-popup-notice-text,
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-container .didomi-popup-notice-data-processing-list,
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-container .didomi-popup-notice-text p,
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-container .didomi-popup-notice-data-processing-list p,
#didomi-host .didomi-notice-data-processing-container .didomi-notice-data-processing-list {
    color: #000 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter', 'Open Sans', sans-serif;
    font-size: 12px !important;
    font-weight: 400 !important;
    line-height: 20px;
    text-align: justify !important;
}
#didomi-host .didomi-notice-data-processing-container .didomi-notice-data-processing-title {
    color: #000 !important;
    font-size: 12px !important;
    font-weight: 400 !important;
}

/*
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice.didomi-popup-notice-with-data-processing p {
    font-family: 'Inter', 'Open Sans', sans-serif;
    font-size: 12px !important;
    line-height: 20px;
    padding-bottom: 16px !important;
}
*/

/* warning/info : normally the 1st p is the title (we had a classname), under that there is a weird <br> in the code, so we reset the padding-bottom to take the br spacing in count */
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-container .didomi-popup-notice-text p.ew-title {
    font-size: 16px !important;
    font-weight: 800;
    padding-bottom: 0 !important;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-mobile .didomi-notice-popup.didomi-support-full-height .didomi-exterior-border .didomi-popup-container .didomi-popup-view .didomi-popup-notice-text-container>:first-child {
    margin-top: 0 !important;
}

/* buttons ------ */
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-view #buttons{
    order: 4;
    flex-direction: column-reverse;
    padding: 16px 24px !important;
}

#didomi-host .didomi-components-button,
#didomi-host .didomi-popup-notice-optin-type .didomi-popup-notice-buttons .didomi-components-button {
    border-radius: 4px !important;
    font-family: 'Inter', 'Open Sans', sans-serif;
    font-size: 12px !important;
}

button#didomi-notice-learn-more-button {
    background-color : transparent !important;
    border: none !important;

pinger-seen="true"></a></div></div></div></div><h2 class="c-article-summary">
        The recently-launched iPhone 15 Pro Max is selling for an eye-watering $1199 in the US, but how do prices differ in Europe?
    </h2><div class="c-article-content c-article-content--business js-article-content poool-content" style="--widget_related_list_trans: 'Related';" id="poool-content" data-poool-session-status="locked"><div class="c-ad u-show-for-mobile-only"><div data-ad-id="adzone-position" class="c-ad__adzone advertising optidigital-mobile-content-1"></div><div class="c-ad__placeholder"><img class="c-ad__placeholder__logo" src="https://static.euronews.com/website/images/logos/logo-euronews-grey-6-180x22.svg" width="180" height="22" alt="" loading="lazy" pinger-seen="true"><span>ADVERTISEMENT</span></div></div><p>If you’re in the Eurozone and you want to buy the top of the range iPhone, it’s going to cost you more than buyers across the pond.</p><p>Converted into euros, the price displayed on Apple’s US website starts at €1131.74 for the iPhone 15 Pro Max, <a href="https://www.euronews.com/2023/09/12/apple-set-to-launch-new-iphones-amidst-sales-slump"><strong>which went on sale in September</strong></a>.</p><p>This is a price hike of around 9% compared to last year’s version, but for European consumers, Americans are arguably bagging a bargain.</p><p>The price in European stores varies between countries, but it’s usually significantly higher than in the US. In France, the iPhone 15 Pro Max starts at €1,479, in Germany it’s €1,449, and in Italy, consumers pay €1,489.</p><div class="od-custom-el"></div><div id="connatix-container-disabled" class="connatix-container"><div id="connatix-player-disabled" data-ad-name="connatix"><script id="bed4ba19931d4bad9e9baedcd606f89f-disabled" defer=""></script></div></div><div class="c-widget-related" data-stories-id="8120672" data-event="widget_related"><div class="c-widget-related__title"><b class="c-widget-related__title__text" lang="en">Related</b></div><ul class="c-widget-related__list"><li class="c-widget-related__item"><a class="c-widget-related__article" href="/business/2023/12/19/apple-to-stop-some-watch-sales-in-us-over-patent-dispute">Apple to stop some watch sales in US over patent dispute</a></li></ul></div><p>When it comes to Apple’s less expensive phones, you’ll also notice a price jump. In the US, the basic iPhone 15 sells for an equivalent of €754.18. Back in Europe, it’s priced at €969 in France, €949 in Germany, and €979 in Italy.</p><div data-optidigital-slot="true" class="optidigital-wrapper-div" style="display: flex !important; align-items: center !important; justify-content: center !important; width: 100% !important; min-width: 468px !important; flex-direction: column !important; min-height: 320px !important; background-color: var(--c-ad-bg-color, var(--color-grey-1)) !important; background-image: url("https://scripts.opti-digital.com/assets/684/logo.svg") !important; background-position: center center !important; background-repeat: no-repeat !important; background-size: 180px 22px !important;"><div class="optidigital-text-ads" style="font-size: 10px !important; font-family: Inter, "Arial size-adjust", Arial, sans-serif !important; padding: 5px 0px !important; margin: 0px !important; color: var(--c-ad-placeholder-color, var(--color-grey-9)) !important; line-height: 1; display: none; position: static !important;"><span style="font-size: 10px !important; position: static !important;">ADVERTISEMENT</span></div><div class="optidigital-brand" style="display: flex !important; flex-direction: column !important; margin: 0px !important; width: 100% !important; align-items: center !important; position: sticky !important; top: 0px !important;"><div id="optidigital-adslot-content_1" data-adslot-id="optidigital-adslot-content_1" class="content_1" style="position: static !important; width: 100% !important;"></div><div class="optidigital-brand-logo" style="display:none;"><a href="https://www.optidigital.com/?utm_medium=aio&utm_source=euronews.com&utm_campaign=content_1" rel="nofollow" class="optidigital-brand-logo-link" target="_blank"></a></div></div></div><div data-oembed-url="https://infogram.com/eleanor-iphone-prices-1hnp27m98zzen2g?live" class="widget widget--type-infogram widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><figure class="widget__figure"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><div class="infogram-embed" data-id="f77eecb0-dafb-4f21-9526-bea488352b62" data-type="interactive" data-title="Eleanor Iphone prices" data-processed="1" id="ig-4b3df1dc-80d4-052e-2440-eeefd4de76ed" style="min-height: 1px;"><iframe src="https://infogram.com/f77eecb0-dafb-4f21-9526-bea488352b62?parent_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.euronews.com%2Fbusiness%2F2023%2F12%2F19%2Fwhy-are-europeans-paying-more-for-their-iphones&src=embed#async_embed" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="" title="Eleanor Iphone prices" style="border: none; width: 650px; height: 655px;"></iframe></div><script defer="">!function(e,n,i,s){var d="InfogramEmbeds";var o=e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];if(window[d]&&window[d].initialized)window[d].process&&window[d].process();else if(!e.getElementById(i)){var r=e.createElement(n);r.async=1,r.id=i,r.src=s,o.parentNode.insertBefore(r,o)}}(document,"script","infogram-async","https://infogram.com/js/dist/embed-loader-min.js");</script></div></div></figure></div></div><p>But before you book your next holiday to America, it’s important to look more closely at these numbers.</p><p>A key reason for the higher prices is that VAT is included in the European figures, whereas extra fees are added after purchase in the US.</p><p>Tax rates depend on which state you’re in, but these generally sit between 2.9% to 7.25%. If you wanted to buy an iPhone 15 Pro Max in Washington, DC, where the sales tax is 6%, you would therefore be charged an extra $71.94 (€67.90) at the checkout.</p><p>To take Los Angeles, where the sales tax is particularly high, you would be charged an extra $113.91 (€107.52).</p><div class="c-widget-related" data-stories-id="8012872" data-event="widget_related"><div class="c-widget-related__title"><b class="c-widget-related__title__text" lang="en">Related</b></div><ul class="c-widget-related__list"><li class="c-widget-related__item"><a class="c-widget-related__article" href="/business/2023/11/03/apple-stocks-fall-as-earnings-shrink-for-fourth-consecutive-quarter">Apple stocks fall as earnings shrink for fourth consecutive quarter</a></li></ul></div><p>So, to tally those figures up, a customer in LA will save €239.74 when buying Apple’s most expensive phone, compared to a customer in France. </p><p>And the price gap between the US and the EU isn’t a phenomenon that’s exclusive to Apple’s new generation of products.</p><p>When the iPhone X was launched in 2017, Twitter users joked that it would be cheaper to fly to the US and buy the device, rather than buying it in Europe.</p><div class="widget widget--type-tweet widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio—auto"><div class="widget__contents"><figure class="widget__figure"><div class="widget__tweet" data-tweet-id="907883402195595265"></div><figcaption class="widget__caption"><span class="widget__captionWrap"><span class="widget__captionText">A Twitter user reacts to the price of the iPhone X, 2017.</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><p>But whilst this may be a good excuse for a holiday, the reality is a little more complicated.</p><div data-optidigital-slot="true" class="optidigital-wrapper-div" style="display: flex !important; align-items: center !important; justify-content: center !important; width: 100% !important; min-width: 468px !important; flex-direction: column !important; min-height: 320px !important; background-color: var(--c-ad-bg-color, var(--color-grey-1)) !important; background-image: url("https://scripts.opti-digital.com/assets/684/logo.svg") !important; background-position: center center !important; background-repeat: no-repeat !important; background-size: 180px 22px !important;"><div class="optidigital-text-ads" style="font-size: 10px !important; font-family: Inter, "Arial size-adjust", Arial, sans-serif !important; padding: 5px 0px !important; margin: 0px !important; color: var(--c-ad-placeholder-color, var(--color-grey-9)) !important; line-height: 1; display: none; position: static !important;"><span style="font-size: 10px !important; position: static !important;">ADVERTISEMENT</span></div><div class="optidigital-brand" style="display: flex !important; flex-direction: column !important; margin: 0px !important; width: 100% !important; align-items: center !important; position: sticky !important; top: 0px !important;"><div id="optidigital-adslot-content_2" data-adslot-id="optidigital-adslot-content_2" class="content_2" style="position: static !important; width: 100% !important;"></div><div class="optidigital-brand-logo" style="display:none;"><a href="https://www.optidigital.com/?utm_medium=aio&utm_source=euronews.com&utm_campaign=content_2" rel="nofollow" class="optidigital-brand-logo-link" target="_blank"></a></div></div></div><p>This is because you are legally required to pay customs duties when re-entering the EU with valuable items.</p><p>If you are travelling on a plane or a ship, you need to declare goods over €430, and for other transport modes, this threshold is at €300. If you were to fly back from the US to France, the customs duties on the iPhone 15 Pro Max would therefore cost you over €200. Along with the added travel costs, this definitely wouldn’t save any money.</p><p>So ultimately, the reason for Apple’s higher prices is not entirely clear, but there’s also no way for Europeans to avoid them.</p><div class="c-widget-related" data-stories-id="7889980" data-event="widget_related"><div class="c-widget-related__title"><b class="c-widget-related__title__text" lang="en">Related</b></div><ul class="c-widget-related__list"><li class="c-widget-related__item"><a class="c-widget-related__article" href="/business/2023/09/12/apple-set-to-launch-new-iphones-amidst-sales-slump">Apple set to launch new iPhones amidst sales slump</a></li></ul></div><p>Addressing the issue in 2016, the company said it sets international product prices based on a range of factors, such as “currency exchange rates, local import laws, business practices, taxes, and the cost of doing business”.</p><p>“These factors vary from region to region and over time, such that international prices are not always comparable to US suggested retail prices,” Apple said.</p><p>Yet even if Apple is making consumers pay more to cover extra operating charges, this hasn’t seemed to dent the company’s success.</p><p>iPhones account for around a quarter of smartphone sales in the EU, surpassed only by Samsung models.</p></div><div class="poool-widget" id="poool-widget"></div><a class="accessibility-bar__goto" href="#accessibility-bar__menu">Go to accessibility shortcuts</a><div
